speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: Chapter Six: The Voice Design Engine. The blue tab is your character creation laboratory. Unlike the Custom Voice engine, there is no pre-trained speaker identity here. You describe the voice you want in plain language, and the model synthesises it from zero.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: This engine uses two completely separate prompts that the model combines. The Voice Description defines the consistent, physical qualities of the speaker. Think of it as the character's body. These qualities do not change between takes.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: The Style Instruction defines the current performance. Think of it as the character's mood in this scene. You can generate the same voice description ten times with ten different style instructions, and get ten entirely different emotional performances.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: The results of zero-shot voice design are non-deterministic. The same description can produce slightly different voices on each run. This is normal. When you find a voice you love, pin the Seed number from the header to reproduce it exactly, or save a W A V and use the Clone engine.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: Speaking of which — if you design a voice you want to reuse in a long project, here is the workflow: generate one clean line, save it as W A V from the Session History, then load that W A V into the Voice Clone tab as a reference. The clone engine will then reproduce that character across any text with much higher stability.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: The Voice Design engine is also the engine behind the Batch Studio's Design blocks. When you add a Design block in Batch Studio, you can load any saved profile to use your custom character inside a multi-voice scene.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: Please load Chapter Seven: The Art of Description. We will focus on the craft of writing great voice descriptions for this engine.
